Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating patterns of genetic relatedness and social inequality using ancient DNA

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Socioeconomic inequality is a topic of great concern in modern society, and studies of past populations can shed light on the origins and development of inequality. This doctoral dissertation project will analyze ancient DNA (aDNA) from skeletons at the Nubian site of Kulubnarti (550-800 AD) to better understand how genetic relatedness, physical appearance, health, and socioeconomic inequality intersected in the past. This project will provide a DNA-based framework that demonstrates the power of molecular analyses for exploring the roots of social stratification. The student co-PI will also conduct science education outreach to elementary school-aged children and their parents, with a focus on biocultural approaches for understanding human biological diversity. Ancient DNA methods used in this project will inform future investigations of genetic relatedness in situations where DNA is degraded.

This project is an investigation of whether biogeographic ancestry and genetic relationships align with archaeologically-observed social stratification between a mainland community of landowning farmers and an island community of "underclass" laborers living side-by-side at the Sudanese Nubian site of Kulubnarti (550-800 AD). To determine if social hierarchy at Kulubnarti correlates with genetically distinct subpopulations, this project tests the hypothesis that the "underclass" position of the islanders was a reflection of migrant status while the landowning farmers composed a more genetically stable local population. The investigators will 1) quantify genetic distance between cemetery communities; 2) examine endogamy within each cemetery community; and 3) estimate biogeographic ancestry and phenotypic variation of individuals from each cemetery. After screening 146 DNA libraries, 30 libraries that demonstrate the highest DNA preservation will be enriched and captured using an array of ~1.2 million single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs). The results will reveal the genetic relationships within and between Kulubnarti communities, will produce the first aDNA data from Nubia, and will integrate genetic and archaeological data to examine the biocultural dynamics of social organization in the past.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Kulubnarti, an archaeological site located in the barren Batn el Hajar region of Sudanese Nubia, was home to two subpopulations, or “communities,” buried in separate cemeteries less than 1 kilometer apart in Early Christian times (550–800 CE). Since the excavation of the cemeteries in 1979, decades of bioarchaeological analyses of stress-induced skeletal lesions, growth patterns, and life expectancy have determined that members of the “S community,” who lived and were interred on a rocky Nile island, were exposed to more stress, experienced more disease, and died younger than members of the “R community,” who inhabited and were interred on the adjacent west bank of the Nile River. Despite major differences in health and mortality between the two communities, biodistance studies using craniometrics and discrete dental traits as proxies for genetic variation suggested that these two communities were biologically very similar. Together, these data support a hypothesis of a single Kulubnarti population, biologically related and culturally unified, but divided into socially-distinct communities. However, without direct genetic analysis, the relationship between the two communities and their biogeographic origins and affinities to present-day populations remained poorly resolved.

Compared to other world regions, little ancient DNA research has been pursued using archaeological material from Africa due to the challenges associated with the thermally-driven degradation of DNA. Therefore, this project used optimized ancient DNA methodologies, including processing the cochlear portion of the petrous pyramid to provide bone material for analysis and generating data using a targeted capture of ~1.24 million informative Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNPs) from across the genome, to investigate questions about the population history of the Kulubnarti Nubians from a high-resolution genomic perspective. This project exemplified how ancient DNA can provide meaningful insights about site-specific questions motivated by archaeology, and addressed a significant gap in our knowledge of the genetic population history of this region of Nubia.

Genome-wide ancient DNA data were generated from 14 individuals from each of the two Kulubnarti communities (28 individuals total). Genetic data from these 28 individuals were analyzed to investigate if the S and R communities formed a single genetic population and to assess their ancestry and genetic affinity to present-day populations. In addition, to ensure that the S and R communities were occupying the site of Kulubnarti at the same time, AMS radiocarbon dating was performed using the same 28 samples that were analyzed genetically. Both cemeteries were assigned a mean date of 746 CE, indicating that they were contemporaneous.

Results identified no community-based genetic population substructure at Kulubnarti, suggesting a single genetic population. Excluding the sex-specific parts of the genome, results individuals of both communities were determined to be of mixed ancestry, with both having similar proportions of ancestry related to North Africans and to Sub-Saharan Africans; future work will examine the historical contexts of potentially relevant admixture events. Using a method specifically developed for estimating relatedness using ancient DNA data, three dyads of related individuals were identified at Kulubnarti, including one set of brothers from the R community, and two sets of likely half-siblings or double cousins, one from each community.

However, when sex-specific mitochondrial (mtDNA) and Y chromosome haplogroups were assigned, a unique and unexpected pattern of sex-based variation was seen in each community. Specifically, analysis of uniparental markers revealed that Eurasian-associated patrilineal ancestry was overrepresented in the more impoverished S community, while Eurasian-associated matrilineal ancestry was overrepresented in the more prosperous R community. A hypothetical explanation of these results is that females of Eurasian ancestry could have migrated into Kulubnarti or along the Nile and preferentially introduced their genes into the R community by admixing with males of local ancestry who owned small, valuable plots of farmland; however, more work remains to be done to systematically test this idea.

Overall, these findings revealed a previously-unknown pattern of sex-specific and community-based genetic variation at the ancient Nubian site of Kulubnarti. At the broadest level, this represents an important step toward a clearer understanding of the population histories and genetic relationships of the inhabitants of ancient Nubia and contributes to the development of a DNA-based framework for directly addressing broader questions of temporal and geographical relationships among Nile Valley populations. More narrowly, but as importantly, this project demonstrates how genetic data was made much more meaningful when considered in light of the archaeological insights about social structure at Kulubnarti, highlighting the power of integrating an understanding of social dynamics and archaeological context with ancient DNA data.
